title: FoodSnap
description: A nutrition app that won first place in the OleHacks hackathon. Using the OpenAI REST API, the app, built on the React Native framework, analyzes an image taken by the user to determine ingredients present in food. Then, API requests are made to the FDA's nutrition information database, where nutrition data is scraped and delivered to the user. The project was primarily written with Python for the backend, and javascript for the app/frontend.

title: Custom VST
description: A custom music plugin developed with the VST software development kit. The project involved extensive interprocess communication on a Windows device, allowing me to get very familiar with the Windows platform as a developer. The plugin takes in sound data and modifies it in real time, capable of producing various effects.

title: qSearch
description: Our ability to tackle complicated problems with large amounts of data is completely dependent on the algorithms we use and the processing power available. In order to meaningfully expand the limits of what is possible, algorithms must improve: one of the most promising, generalizable advancements in algorithms is Grover’s quantum search algorithm, which is capable of searching a disorganized solution space in O(n1/2) time. Although classical sorting algorithms can allow for even faster lookups, when the limit for a problem becomes size itself and the question becomes “Can we do it at all?” rather than “How fast can we do it?” a fundamentally more efficient approach is required. In the interest of making Grover’s algorithm more accessible, as well as assessing it’s current viability, this project will focus on implementing it on real, public IBM quantum computers, visualizing and analyzing the results in comparison to classical search algorithms, documenting the reduction process that would apply Grover’s algorithm to other search problems, and, finally, experimenting with adjustments in an attempt to find leverageable modifications to improve outcomes.

title: Robot Navigation
description: The second part of my REU at the University of Texas-Arlington. Together with a partner, a novel navigation stack was created on the ROS framework, in an attempt to see if high level sensor fusion of LiDAR and model-processed camera data could improve navigation sensitivity and robustness.

title: AnyFile
description: My final Software Design project. With a team of two others, I developed software, from scratch, that could perform basic media file type conversions. C++ allowed us to work on a very low level, getting valuable experience manipulating granular data and using compression techniques like Huffman Encoding and the discrete cosine transform. We also implemented a user-friendly UI with React Native.

title: This Website I Suppose
description: Created using the Google Cloud Platform (GCP), with an Express server.
